For many companies, the COVID-19 has meant a real challenge as they were forced to adapt to new ways of working. From this pandemic, however, we can learn some valuable lessons to keep us productive during these tough times. Here are five things we can learn from and how to apply them to software development. #WeStayAtHome #Productive #management'

The difficult situation the world is living nowadays has opened the need to manage budget wisely due to the uncertain future. Hiring a nearshore company that offers you very competitive and lower rates, without compromising quality, is essential. Take into account that thanks to the cultural affinity, they also can understand your current needs better and be the consultant company you are in need of. #nearshore #outsourcing #softwaredevelopment'

Set specific goals and tasks for each day and communicate them to the team. This will help to keep track of every task everyone is working on and not missing details due to the physical absence. #WeStayAtHome #workingremotely'

Even in these days, you can still count on friends and family. It can be difficult to be in quarantine for 14 days, but it will be more difficult to not get in touch with your loved ones. Take some time during the day -maybe lunchtime- to phonecall someone. This will be a great break and it will give you energy to continue with your daily job. #WeStayAtHome #workingremotely'

Connectivity is the clue when it comes to working with remote teams. Make sure your WiFi connection and Internet provider works perfectly. Think about increasing velocity if your project needs it or make sure the IT team of your company will technically respond as if it was at the office. #WeStayAtHome #workfromhome'

Schedule some minutes along the day and make indoor exercise. You can always look for a free app or videos to practice a yoga or stretching routine. Get the best out of the quarantine time. #WeStayAtHome #fitness #workfromhome #productive'

"Being alone at home can difficult communication. You don't have your colleague next to you or your daily meetings might be postponed. If written communication is the most common used tool during these days, make sure the idea is clear and accurate. Send the message only if you're sure there are no misunderstandings. #WeStayAtHome"

"In these COVID-19 times where companies have been forced to change the way they work, some of them might be evaluating making a twist in their outsourcing strategies. Is this time to look into another location? Many markets are facing total lockdowns and software projects might have important delays due to technical issues. Nearshore software companies are 100% technically prepared to non-stop your business's productivity. #nearshore #outsourcing #softwaredevelopment"

Experts say that 20-minute morning coffee or afternoon exercise, can put you in the right working mindset. Not talking with your colleagues and sometimes not even standing up from the chair can make things worse. Let your mind go blank for a few minutes. #WeStayAtHome #workingremotely'

Buy yourself or bring from the office the right monitor, webcam, headset, mouse, keyboard, and an extra USB hub & dock, these will definitely help you during your home office days. Wake up a couple of minutes early every morning and make sure everything is running and working properly. You will have a smooth day! #WeStayAtHome #workfromhome #productive'

If you\'re trying to be productive, these "home office" days are not the excuse for not to. Set one specific room and avoid working from the bed. Get ready, as every morning, get dressed, and make yourself comfortable to start your work with the right foot. #WeStayAtHome #productivity #workingremotely'

"Continued communication will guarantee that your project won't be affected by these hectic days. Make sure your team has the proper communication tools in order to keep all members in contact at any time. #WeStayAtHome #workingremotely #productive"

"The FBI released an advisory yesterday about credential stuffing in the #financial services industry. The tools used in these campaigns like SentryMBA and SNIPR make detecting these attacks with traditional indicators like IP addresses less than effective. At MX we are often the first to identify credential stuffing campaigns against smaller FI's because of our ability to model login behaviors. I would be happy to chat with anyone that needs help figuring out behavioral models related to these attacks and how indicators such as JA3 can be useful in identifying repeat offenders. Also would love to hear anyone else's thoughts on effective ways of sharing TTP's of these threat actors across the industry. #threatintelligence #threatdetection #credentialstuffing"

‚ÄúA strong #PersonalFinance solution should be guiding and nudging you toward smarter spending habits,‚Äù says Nate Gardner, chief customer officer at MX. ‚ÄúThe app should start to alert you if you have multiple subscriptions or if you‚Äôre going to exceed your credit limit. Perhaps it can help make you aware of how you compare against a broader population. Those features can be incredibly helpful.‚Äù The entire foundation of personal financial management is to eliminate spreadsheets and extra work. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre still having to do an enormous amount of work to get the data correct, the value of the tool is diminished significantly,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIf the data is unstructured and unclean, you‚Äôre no better off than before you started using it.‚Äù ‚ÄúFind a solution that will allow you to pull in all your accounts,‚Äù Gardner says. ‚ÄúIf you can get all of your transaction data in one place and the tool will do some of the categorizing work for you, you can then confirm if the data is accurate.‚Äù‚ÄúThe mobile experience of using a financial tool should feel equivalent to what Tesla is in the auto industry,‚Äù Gardner says. ‚ÄúInstead of just driving you from point A to point B, it should also watch out for your safety and give you warnings about where to turn and how to avoid accidents.‚Äùvia Bankrate'

Looking back at 2020 challenges & opportunities, what trends can we expect to emerge for the financial industry in 2021?MX CTO, Brandon Dewitt, shared his 2021 predictions w/ PaymentsSource.1. Greater banking access embraces open financeOpen finance empowers consumers to access, leverage, and take action on their data. The trend will lead to focused attention on customer data advocacy and the emergence of new business models.2. Post-recession savings habits to surgeA savings surge is coming. Consumers will increase the percentage saved, largely to prepare for future economic challenges.As we deal with more saving than spending, we should look to companies like those in Japan for how their banking system handles. When there are net savers vs. spenders, we could see negative interest rates on savings accounts.3. Financial advocacy turns transactions into experiences 2021 is the year to shift focus from being financial go-betweens to advocates for customers. Move beyond transactions to experiences. Reports of financial & economic abuse are on the rise - are banks doing enough to help?Our Chief Advocacy Officer, Jane Barratt joined the 11:FS Fintech Insider Podcast to discuss.  Listen now üéß:  https://fi.11fs.com/655‚ÄúWe often try to solve cultural problems with tech solutions. Abuse is a culturally taboo topic in our society, but so is talking about money. We‚Äôre launching people out into the world with 1950s models where the man takes care of everything. If there‚Äôs one thing we as tech people can do it‚Äôs to talk more about this taboo topic. Everyone should have access to their own finances. Even with joint accounts, you should know your credit score. Our mission at MX is to empower the world to be financially strong. And step one for empowerment is financial transparency.‚Äù ‚ÄúFinancial institutions should be watching out for the financial health of all their account holders. If they see what appears to be a financially healthy couple, & yet one partner shows a very healthy credit score & the other has a terrible one, that should be a red flag. That data needs to be pulled apart. We are seeing at least step one happening, which is engaging in the conversation.We have to redefine what financial health truly is, and then everything else can follow.‚Äù'
